newsitem.title: JAPAN: Big Japanese firms show 15% rise in interim profit.
newsitem.headline: Big Japanese firms show 15% rise in interim profit.

text.p: Interim earnings figures from more than 550 major Japanese firms showed an average increase in profit of nearly 15 percent, a corporate survey showed on Monday.
Wako Research Institute of Economics said the parent current profits of the firms increased by an average of 14.52 percent in the first half of the 1996/97 business year.
Current profit is pre-tax profit which includes gains and losses made on securities investments and other non-operating activities.
The research arm of Wako Securities Co based its figures on the interim parent current profit results of 565 firms.
It tracks 766 large companies, all of which are listed on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange and have business years ending on March 31.
The list does not include banks, brokerages or insurance firms. Not all the firms have released their interim results yet.
The after-tax parent profit of the 565 firms increased 14.67 percent in the interim period compared with the previous year, while parent sales were up 4.65 percent, the survey said.
The parent current profits of car makers and auto parts manufacturers surged 152.97 percent, while those of real estate developers dropped by an average of 67.64 percent, the survey said.
The average year-on-year gain in the 565 firms' parent current profits in the previous six-month period to March 31 was 29.01 percent, Wako said.
